verses.text: After Rehoboam's kingdom was established and he had become strong, he abandoned the law of the LORD, and all Israel followed him in this.
verses.comment: Retains the original sense of national apostasy; 'abandoned the law' is a modern rendering for clarity.

verses.text: In the fifth year of King Rehoboam, Shishak king of Egypt came up against Jerusalem, because they had been unfaithful to the LORD.
verses.comment: Emphasizes Egypt's invasion as God's judgment for Israel's unfaithfulness.

verses.text: He came with twelve hundred chariots, sixty thousand horsemen, and troops who were uncountable that came with him out of Egypt—Libyans, Sukkiim, and Cushites.
verses.comment: Lists Egyptian allies per Hebrew text; maintains ancient people groups’ names.

verses.text: He seized the fortified cities of Judah and came as far as Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Simple, direct; ‘seized’ translates ‘captured’ or ‘took possession of’.

verses.text: Then Shemaiah the prophet came to Rehoboam and to the leaders of Judah who had gathered in Jerusalem because of Shishak, and he said to them, 'Thus says the LORD: You have abandoned me, so I have also abandoned you to Shishak.'
verses.comment: God’s reciprocal abandonment is explicit; refrains from interpretive language.

verses.text: Then the officials of Israel and the king humbled themselves and said, 'The LORD is righteous.'
verses.comment: Their confession matches the Hebrew phrase; ‘humbled themselves’ is standard.

verses.text: When the LORD saw that they humbled themselves, the word of the LORD came to Shemaiah, saying, 'They have humbled themselves; I will not destroy them, but I will soon grant them some deliverance, and my wrath will not be poured out on Jerusalem by the hand of Shishak.'
verses.comment: ‘Some deliverance’ translates the Hebrew concept of partial relief; the phrase is not total deliverance.

verses.text: However, they will be servants to him, so that they may learn the difference between serving me and serving the kingdoms of the earth.
verses.comment: The Hebrew here does not soften servitude; ‘kingdoms of the earth’ follows the literal meaning.

verses.text: So Shishak king of Egypt attacked Jerusalem, and took away the treasures of the house of the LORD and the treasures of the king's house. He took everything. He also took away the gold shields that Solomon had made.
verses.comment: ‘Took everything’ is faithful to the Hebrew's emphatic ‘he took away all.’

verses.text: King Rehoboam made bronze shields to replace them and entrusted them to the captains of the guard who watched over the entrance to the king's house.
verses.comment: ‘Entrusted’ is a modern equivalent for ‘gave into the hands’; ‘bronze’ is correct for Hebrew ‘nechosheth’.

verses.text: Whenever the king entered the house of the LORD, the guards would carry them, and then return them to the guard chamber.
verses.comment: Describes the ritual; slight rewording for readability, same meaning.

verses.text: When Rehoboam humbled himself, the LORD’s anger turned away from him, so as not to destroy him completely. Moreover, there were still some good things found in Judah.
verses.comment: Maintains the nuance: God’s wrath lessened, not fully removed.

verses.text: So King Rehoboam strengthened his position in Jerusalem and reigned. He was forty-one years old when he began to reign, and he reigned seventeen years in Jerusalem, the city the LORD had chosen out of all the tribes of Israel to put His name there. His mother’s name was Naamah the Ammonite.
verses.comment: Follows standard genealogical listing; ‘to put His name there’ is literal phrasing.

verses.text: And he did evil, because he did not set his heart to seek the LORD.
verses.comment: Retains emphasis on intentionality (‘set his heart’), matches Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: As for the events of Rehoboam’s reign, from beginning to end, are they not written in the chronicles of Shemaiah the prophet and of Iddo the seer, covering genealogies? There was continual war between Rehoboam and Jeroboam.
verses.comment: ‘Covering genealogies’ clarifies the role of the texts; war is specified as ongoing.

verses.text: Rehoboam rested with his ancestors and was buried in the city of David. Abijah his son became king in his place.
verses.comment: ‘Rested with his ancestors’ translates Hebrew idiom; ‘in his place’ for succession.
